awd_titl_txt: Network Structure and Conflict Management in a Cooperatively Breeding Fish
awd_abstract_narration:
Human and non-human animals live in "social networks" of interactions and relationships.  For example, one animal might interact frequently with its groupmates, while another rarely does so.  An animal might be aggressive to another, but interact peacefully with yet others.  The researchers will investigate how these social networks change after conflict to either make conflict worse in the future, or to prevent conflict from re-emerging. The researchers hypothesize that social networks that we observe in nature will tend to change in ways that limit further conflict for two reasons.  First, we might not have much of a chance to observe networks that do not do so, as otherwise conflict becomes so severe that the whole group quickly breaks apart. Second, individual animals may benefit from avoiding conflict, and so they modify their behavior in ways that reduce the risks of further conflict.  To test this hypothesis, the researchers propose to explore how social networks change after conflict in the cichlid fish Neolamprologus pulcher, which live in stable, long-lasting groups using dynamical network models coupled with experiments in nature.  If social networks change in ways that limit conflict, this would help understand how groups of individuals with competing interests are able to stay together and prevent day-to-day quarrels from escalating. This project involves international collaboration in Zambia and training of students in both mathematical and biological research. This project is co-funded by the Animal Behavior program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, the Mathematical Biology program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences, the BIOMAPS program for proposals at the interface of Biology, Math and the Physical Sciences, and from the Office of International Science and Engineering. 

The researchers propose to perturb groups of N pulcher in the laboratory and the field, for example by removing individuals to create opportunities for others to change social status.  They will conduct intensive behavioral observations on all group members before and after perturbation. They propose to use stochastic actor oriented models (SAOM) to analyze social network change. Stochastic actor-oriented models are a type of time ordered dynamic network model in which individual behaviors and network structures coevolve. They propose to use mathematical and computational models to test whether the patterns of connections found from the SAOM analyses are associated with low levels of conflict and high group stability.  Finally, the researchers propose to measure stress hormone (cortisol) levels and reproductive success to investigate whether individuals benefit from being in groups that are better able to limit conflict.  Findings from this research will provide insights into how individuals' social environment emerges through the effects of their interactions with one another, the resilience of the social environment to perturbation, and how the emergent social environment feeds back on individual performance and reproductive success.

por.por_cntn:
Living in stable, long-term groups can be beneficial.  However, group members can be in conflict with one another over resources, mates, and social status.  What is it that makes some groups stable in the face of such conflict while others fail? When does natural selection acting on individuals favor strategies that successfully manage conflict at the level of the group? In this project, we sought to explore the causes and consequences of conflict in group-living animals and to understand when and how conflict in animal societies is managed. To do so, used a combination of mathematical models and experimental work on a group-living African cichlid fish (Neolamprologus pulcher). Groups of N. pulcher typically consist of a large dominant male, a large dominant female, and one or more smaller, subordinates.  Groups are strongly size structured, with larger individuals dominant to smaller individuals.  Conflict can be particularly severe when group members are similar in size to one another.  We can observe and manipulate N. pulcher groups in the field and under controlled laboratory conditions, making this species ideal for studying cooperation and conflict.

One of our key objectives was to understand the formation of stable social groups that are resilient to disturbance. Previous work showed that male N. pulcher adjust their growth to size differences with other males, growing quickly if the next largest male is large and slowly if the next largest male is relatively small. We used models to understand whether such adjustments would give rise to the observed relationship between dominance and size and whether this reduces conflict among group members.  We found three possible relationships between size and dominance in our models: 1) dominants and subordinates are the same size, 2) dominants are larger than subordinates and size differences continue to grow over time, or 3) dominants are larger than subordinates, but size differences stabilize over time.  The third pattern, which is consistent with what we see in N. pulcher, was associated with low levels of conflict.  In an evolutionary model, behaviors that gave rise to this pattern evolved under realistic conditions.  Each of these patterns can be stable, but there are sharp transitions among these patterns. In other words, there are ?tipping points? which, if crossed, shift the system from one pattern to another. Understanding the drivers that can push societies from one pattern to another may help us predict when and where social instability emerges in groups of N. pulcher and other societies. 

Winner and loser effects, in which individuals that have experience winning (or losing) contests are more likely to win (or lose) in the future, also contribute to the formation of stable dominance hierarchies. Animals living in long-term groups, like N. pulcher, have multiple, repeated interactions with groupmates, so we explored how cumulative social experiences ? and the consistency of those experiences ? influenced behavior in staged conflicts. Consistent past experiences reinforced aggressive behavior; for example, individuals that won contests in the past repeatedly were more aggressive in staged conflicts than individuals that lost repeatedly.  Inconsistent past experiences weakened these effects.

To explore whether the structure of wild groups of N. pulcher was related to their resilience, we collected over 170 hours of videos from our field site in Lake Tanganyika at Kasakalawe, Zambia. We hypothesized that groups with a well-resolved dominance hierarchy would be more resilient to experimental disturbance. We have collected a large, rich data set and analysis of these data is ongoing. 

We sought to explore whether there were physiological consequences of social instability and physiological drivers of social instability. We predicted that a consequence of social instability would be changes in steroid hormone levels associated with stress responses and aggressive behavior. While we found that steroid hormones were associated with social rank, we did not find evidence that steroid hormone levels influenced or responded to social instability in the field or in the lab. 

During collection of field data, we took the opportunity to investigate an underexplored social interaction involving interactions between different species of fish from Lake Tanganyika: apparent joint hunting behavior by predatory cichlids and spiny eels. We documented cases in which eels hunted simultaneously with four different species of cichlids; we are currently testing whether such associations occurred more frequently than expected by chance and whether joint hunting behavior is associated with higher rates of prey capture.

This project involved several broader impacts beyond expanding our understanding of social instability.  These included the development and implementation of an educational module on social network analysis aimed at biology and mathematics undergraduates, a summer camp on coding and modeling that was offered to middle and high school students each year from 2019-2021, international collaboration, mentoring of students from underrepresented minorities, and mentoring and training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers.
